    (P : ℕ → Prop)
    (P_def : ∀ n, P n ↔ ∀ (G : Type) [Group G] [Finite G],
      ∀ H : Fin n → Subgroup G, (∀ i, H i < ⊤) → ⋃ i, (H i : Set G) < ⊤) :

      simp_all

  exact ⟨h₁, h₂⟩

theorem putnam_1969_b2
    (P : ℕ → Prop)
    (P_def : ∀ n, P n ↔ ∀ (G : Type) [Group G] [Finite G],
      ∀ H : Fin n → Subgroup G, (∀ i, H i < ⊤) → ⋃ i, (H i : Set G) < ⊤) :

      intro G _ _ H hH
      -- We need to show that the union of the subgroups H i is strictly contained in G
      have h₁ : ⋃ i, (H i : Set G) < ⊤ := by
        simp_all [SetLike.coe_mono]
        <;>
        exact?
      simpa using h₁
    simpa using h₁
  
  have h₂ : P 3 ↔ putnam_1969_b2_solution := by

```lean4
import Mathlib

open Matrix Filter Topology Set Nat

abbrev putnam_1969_b2_solution : Prop := sorry
-- False
/--
Show that a finite group can not be the union of two of its proper subgroups. Does the statement remain true if 'two' is replaced by 'three'?
-/
theorem putnam_1969_b2
    (P : ℕ → Prop)
    (P_def : ∀ n, P n ↔ ∀ (G : Type) [Group G] [Finite G],
      ∀ H : Fin n → Subgroup G, (∀ i, H i < ⊤) → ⋃ i, (H i : Set G) < ⊤) :
    P 2 ∧ (P 3 ↔ putnam_1969_b2_solution) :=
  sorry

```lean4
theorem putnam_1969_b2
    (P : ℕ → Prop)
    (P_def : ∀ n, P n ↔ ∀ (G : Type) [Group G] [Finite G],
      ∀ H : Fin n → Subgroup G, (∀ i, H i < ⊤) → ⋃ i, (H i : Set G) < ⊤) :
    P 2 ∧ (P 3 ↔ putnam_1969_b2_solution) := by
  have h₀ : P 2 := by
    rw [P_def]
    intro G _ _ H H_lt_top
    -- We need to show that the union of two proper subgroups is not the whole group.
    -- This is a contradiction because the union of two proper subgroups cannot cover the whole group.
    apply lt_top_iff_ne_top.mpr
    intro h
    have h₁ : ⋃ i, (H i : Set G) = ⊤ := by simpa using h
    have h₂ : ∀ i, H i < ⊤ := by simpa using H_lt_top
    have h₃ : ∀ i, H i ≠ ⊤ := by
      intro i
      intro h₄
      have h₅ : H i < ⊤ := H_lt_top i
      have h₆ : H i = ⊤ := by simpa using h₄
      simp_all
    have h₄ : ⋃ i, (H i : Set G) ≠ ⊤ := by
      intro h₅
      have h₆ : ∃ i, H i = ⊤ := by
        by_contra! h₇
        have h₈ : ⋃ i, (H i : Set G) = ⊤ := by simpa using h₅
        simp_all [Set.ext_iff]
        <;> aesop
      rcases h₆ with ⟨i, h₇⟩
      have h₈ : H i = ⊤ := h₇
      have h₉ : H i ≠ ⊤ := h₃ i
      simp_all
    simp_all
  have h₁ : P 3 ↔ putnam_1969_b2_solution := by
    rw [P_def]
    constructor
    · intro h
      exact by
        -- Assume P(3) is true and derive the solution.
        exact h
    · intro h
      intro G _ _ H H_lt_top
      -- We need to show that the union of three proper subgroups is not the whole group.
      -- This is a contradiction because the union of three proper subgroups cannot cover the whole group.
      apply lt_top_iff_ne_top.mpr
      intro h₁
      have h₂ : ⋃ i, (H i : Set G) = ⊤ := by simpa using h₁
      have h₃ : ∀ i, H i < ⊤ := by simpa using H_lt_top
      have h₄ : ∀ i, H i ≠ ⊤ := by
        intro i
        intro h₅
        have h₆ : H i < ⊤ := H_lt_top i
        have h₇ : H i = ⊤ := by simpa using h₅
        simp_all
      have h₅ : ⋃ i, (H i : Set G) ≠ ⊤ := by
        intro h₆
        have h₇ : ∃ i, H i = ⊤ := by
          by_contra! h₈
          have h₉ : ⋃ i, (H i : Set G) = ⊤ := by simpa using h₆
          simp_all [Set.ext_iff]
          <;> aesop
        rcases h₇ with ⟨i, h₈⟩
        have h₉ : H i = ⊤ := h₈
        have h₁₀ : H i ≠ ⊤ := h₄ i
        simp_all
      simp_all
  exact ⟨h₀, h₁⟩
```

import Mathlib

open Matrix Filter Topology Set Nat

abbrev putnam_1969_b2_solution : Prop := sorry
-- False
/--
Show that a finite group can not be the union of two of its proper subgroups. Does the statement remain true if 'two' is replaced by 'three'?
-/
theorem putnam_1969_b2
    (P : ℕ → Prop)
    (P_def : ∀ n, P n ↔ ∀ (G : Type) [Group G] [Finite G],
      ∀ H : Fin n → Subgroup G, (∀ i, H i < ⊤) → ⋃ i, (H i : Set G) < ⊤) :
    P 2 ∧ (P 3 ↔ putnam_1969_b2_solution) :=
  sorry

```lean4
theorem putnam_1969_b2
    (P : ℕ → Prop)
    (P_def : ∀ n, P n ↔ ∀ (G : Type) [Group G] [Finite G],
      ∀ H : Fin n → Subgroup G, (∀ i, H i < ⊤) → ⋃ i, (H i : Set G) < ⊤) :
    P 2 ∧ (P 3 ↔ putnam_1969_b2_solution) := by
  have h₁ : P 2 := by
    have h₁ : ∀ (G : Type) [Group G] [Finite G], ∀ H : Fin 2 → Subgroup G, (∀ i, H i < ⊤) → ⋃ i, (H i : Set G) < ⊤ := by
      intro G _ _ H hH
      have h₁ : ⋃ i, (H i : Set G) < ⊤ := by
        have h₂ : ⋃ i, (H i : Set G) ≤ ⊤ := by simp
        have h₃ : ⋃ i, (H i : Set G) ≠ ⊤ := by
          intro h
          have h₄ : ⊤ ≤ ⋃ i, (H i : Set G) := by simp_all
          have h₅ : ∃ i, H i = ⊤ := by
            simp_all [SetLike.ext'_iff]
            <;> aesop
          rcases h₅ with ⟨i, hi⟩
          have h₆ : H i < ⊤ := hH i
          simp_all [SetLike.lt_iff_le_and_ne]
        exact lt_top_iff_ne_top.mpr h₃
      exact h₁
    exact by simpa using h₁
  
  have h₂ : P 3 ↔ putnam_1969_b2_solution := by
    have h₂ : ∀ (G : Type) [Group G] [Finite G], ∀ H : Fin 3 → Subgroup G, (∀ i, H i < ⊤) → ⋃ i, (H i : Set G) < ⊤ ↔ putnam_1969_b2_solution := by
      simp_all [putnam_1969_b2_solution]
      <;>
        exact ⟨fun h => by
          have h₃ := h (fun i => ⊤)
          have h₄ := h (fun i => ⊥)
          aesop,
          fun h => by
            have h₃ := h
            aesop⟩
    simpa [h₁] using h₂
  
  exact ⟨h₁, h₂⟩
```

-- False
/--
Show that a finite group can not be the union of two of its proper subgroups. Does the statement remain true if 'two' is replaced by 'three'?
-/
theorem putnam_1969_b2
    (P : ℕ → Prop)
    (P_def : ∀ n, P n ↔ ∀ (G : Type) [Group G] [Finite G],
      ∀ H : Fin n → Subgroup G, (∀ i, H i < ⊤) → ⋃ i, (H i : Set G) < ⊤) :
    P 2 ∧ (P 3 ↔ putnam_1969_b2_solution) :=

```lean4
theorem putnam_1969_b2
    (P : ℕ → Prop)
    (P_def : ∀ n, P n ↔ ∀ (G : Type) [Group G] [Finite G],
      ∀ H : Fin n → Subgroup G, (∀ i, H i < ⊤) → ⋃ i, (H i : Set G) < ⊤) :
    P 2 ∧ (P 3 ↔ putnam_1969_b2_solution) := by
  have h₁ : P 2 := by
    rw [P_def]
    intro G _ _ H H_lt_top
    -- We need to show that the union of two proper subgroups is not the whole group.
    -- This is a contradiction, hence the union cannot be the whole group.
    have h₂ : ⋃ i, (H i : Set G) < ⊤ := by
      simp_all [SetLike.coe_mono]
      <;> exact?
    exact h₂
  have h₂ : P 3 ↔ putnam_1969_b2_solution := by
    rw [P_def]
    -- We need to show that for any group G of finite order, the union of three proper subgroups cannot be the whole group.
    -- This is a known result in group theory.
    have h₃ : ∀ (G : Type) [Group G] [Finite G], ∀ H : Fin 3 → Subgroup G, (∀ i, H i < ⊤) → ⋃ i, (H i : Set G) < ⊤ := by
      intro G _ _ H H_lt_top
      -- We use the fact that the union of three proper subgroups cannot cover the whole group.
      have h₄ : ⋃ i, (H i : Set G) < ⊤ := by
        simp_all [SetLike.coe_mono]
        <;> exact?
      exact h₄
    have h₄ : ∀ (G : Type) [Group G] [Finite G], ∀ H : Fin 3 → Subgroup G, (∀ i, H i < ⊤) → ⋃ i, (H i : Set G) < ⊤ := by
      intro G _ _ H H_lt_top
      -- We use the fact that the union of three proper subgroups cannot cover the whole group.
      have h₅ : ⋃ i, (H i : Set G) < ⊤ := by
        simp_all [SetLike.coe_mono]
        <;> exact?
      exact h₅
    exact Iff.intro (fun h => by
      -- If P 3 holds, then the union of three proper subgroups cannot cover the whole group.
      exact? ) (fun h => by
      -- If the union of three proper subgroups cannot cover the whole group, then P 3 holds.
      exact? )
  exact ⟨h₁, h₂⟩
```

theorem putnam_1969_b2
    (P : ℕ → Prop)
    (P_def : ∀ n, P n ↔ ∀ (G : Type) [Group G] [Finite G],
      ∀ H : Fin n → Subgroup G, (∀ i, H i < ⊤) → ⋃ i, (H i : Set G) < ⊤) :
    P 2 ∧ (P 3 ↔ putnam_1969_b2_solution) := by
  have h₁ : P 2 := by
    have h₁ : P 2 := by
      have h₁ : ∀ (G : Type) [Group G] [Finite G], ∀ H : Fin 2 → Subgroup G, (∀ i, H i < ⊤) → ⋃ i, (H i : Set G) < ⊤ := by
        intro G _ _ H hH
        have h₁ : ⋃ i, (H i : Set G) < ⊤ := by
          have h₂ : ⋃ i, (H i : Set G) = Set.univ := by
            have h₃ : ∀ x : G, x ∈ ⋃ i, (H i : Set G) := by
              intro x
              have h₄ : x ∈ H 0 := by
                have h₅ := hH 0
                have h₆ := hH 1
                simp_all [lt_top_iff_ne_top, SetLike.mem_coe]
                <;> aesop
              simp_all [Set.mem_iUnion]
              <;> aesop
            simp_all [Set.eq_univ_iff_forall]
          simp_all [Set.lt_univ_iff]
          <;> aesop
        exact h₁
      exact by simpa using h₁
    exact h₁
  
  have h₂ : P 3 ↔ putnam_1969_b2_solution := by
    have h₂ : P 3 ↔ putnam_1969_b2_solution := by
      have h₃ : P 3 := by
        have h₃ : ∀ (G : Type) [Group G] [Finite G], ∀ H : Fin 3 → Subgroup G, (∀ i, H i < ⊤) → ⋃ i, (H i : Set G) < ⊤ := by
          intro G _ _ H hH
          have h₃ : ⋃ i, (H i : Set G) < ⊤ := by
            have h₄ : ⋃ i, (H i : Set G) = Set.univ := by
              have h₅ : ∀ x : G, x ∈ ⋃ i, (H i : Set G) := by
                intro x
                have h₆ : x ∈ H 0 := by
                  have h₇ := hH 0
                  have h₈ := hH 1
                  have h₉ := hH 2
                  simp_all [lt_top_iff_ne_top, SetLike.mem_coe]
                  <;> aesop
                simp_all [Set.mem_iUnion]
                <;> aesop
              simp_all [Set.eq_univ_iff_forall]
            simp_all [Set.lt_univ_iff]
            <;> aesop
          exact h₃
        exact by simpa using h₃
      have h₄ : P 3 ↔ putnam_1969_b2_solution := by
        simp_all [P_def]
        <;> aesop
      exact h₄
    exact h₂
  
  have h₃ : P 2 ∧ (P 3 ↔ putnam_1969_b2_solution) := by
    exact ⟨h₁, h₂⟩
  exact h₃
```
